question: 某
sourceAnswer:
<read>ぼう</read>:: certain/one | I/me
<read>なにがし</read>|<read>なにぼう</read>:<tag><ja>何がし</ja></tag>:: certain-amount/some | certain-person/Mr-So-and-so/a-certain-... | I/me

<tag><read>ぼう</read>:pre|suff:</tag> a-certain/one/{mr/ms}-so-and-so/someone-or-other
<tag><read>なにがし</read>|<read>なにぼう</read>:</tag> certain-amount/some | a-certain/one/{mr/ms}-so-and-so | <tag><read>なにがし</read>:arch:</tag>I/me
sourceMnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>certain</kanji>, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like <vocabulary>someone or other</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>you-know-who</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>something</vocabulary>. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You bump into <vocabulary>someone or other</vocabulary>, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her <reading>nanny gashe</reading>s (<ja>なにがし</ja>) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor <vocabulary>you-know-who</vocabulary>, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.
